conversation.message: Hello School_D admissions committee. I’m Student_C, and School_D is my first-choice school. I’m applying because your program and environment fit my goals very well, and if accepted I will commit to enrolling. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_D. School_D’s priority list ranks Student_D and Student_E above me, so I’m not guaranteed acceptance if they apply. However, applying immediately is still my best chance to secure my first choice before the seat is taken. I will send a clear, committed application emphasizing School_D is my first choice and I will enroll if accepted.

conversation.message: Student_C, thank you for your application and for naming School_D as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission—welcome to School_D. Please confirm your enrollment commitment and we will proceed with the next steps for registration and orientation.
conversation.thought: Student_C is currently applying and ranks 3rd on School_D’s true priority list (behind Student_D and Student_E). However, in this round only Student_C contacted us, and Student_C’s preferences place School_D as #1, making the match stable/secure if we accept. Waiting risks losing Student_C to another school only if we reject; Student_D and Student_E are unlikely to apply to School_D early because Student_D ranks School_D last and Student_E ranks School_D 4th. Given quota 1 and low likelihood of higher-priority applicants coming, accepting Student_C now maximizes expected outcome.

conversation.message: Hello School_C admissions team. I’m Student_D, and School_C is my first choice. I’m especially interested in your academic environment and would be excited to contribute to the community. I’m ready to commit if offered a seat. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is School_C. I have relatively high priority there (3rd), so applying immediately gives me a strong chance before other high-priority students try. Even if Student_C (their top priority) applies, I still want to be considered early and signal strong commitment.

conversation.message: Student_D, thank you for your application and for naming School_C as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission—welcome to School_C. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority list ranks Student_D (3rd) above Student_E (4th) and Student_A (5th), but below Student_C (1st) and Student_B (2nd). In round 1, only Student_D and Student_E applied. Accepting Student_D now guarantees a relatively high-ranked match and fills my only quota. However, Student_C and Student_B both rank School_C low (4th and 5th respectively), so it is unlikely they will apply to me later unless rejected elsewhere; waiting risks ending with a lower-ranked applicant or no match. Since Student_D has School_C as first choice and is applying with commitment, accepting is a strong, low-risk outcome compared to holding out for unlikely higher-priority applicants.

conversation.message: School_C is my first choice. I’m applying because I strongly want to join your program and would commit enthusiastically if accepted. I’m ready to contribute academically and to school activities—thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_C, so I should apply immediately. Although School_C ranks me 4th, early application gives me a chance if higher-priority students choose other schools. I will signal strong commitment and fit to encourage acceptance if they have discretion among applicants.

conversation.message: Student_E, thank you for applying and for your strong interest in School_C. At this time, we have already filled our available seat and are unable to extend an offer this round. We appreciate your application and wish you the best in the remaining process. [REJECT]
conversation.thought: Our quota is already filled (Remaining Quota: 0) with Student_D, with whom we have an established match via [ACCEPT]. Per rules, when quota is 0 we must reject any new [APPLY] regardless of priority. Student_E is also below Student_D on our true priority list, and we cannot displace an existing match in this protocol.

conversation.message: Hello School_A Admissions Committee—I'm Student_B. School_A is one of my top choices, and I would be excited to join and contribute to the school community. I’m especially interested in a rigorous academic environment and would be happy to share more about my interests and goals. Thank you for your consideration—I would like to formally apply.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_B, but I am only 3rd in School_B’s priority list (behind Student_D and Student_A), so applying there in round 1 is likely to be rejected if they apply. I am 1st in School_A’s priority list, and School_A is my 3rd choice, so applying to School_A gives me a strong chance to secure a good match early rather than risk ending up with a much lower option later.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

Thank you for your application and for sharing your interest in School_A’s rigorous academic environment. We’re pleased to offer you admission.

[ACTION: If you still wish to enroll, please confirm your intent to proceed.]

Congratulations, and we look forward to welcoming you to School_A.

Sincerely,
School_A Admissions

Student_B is my top-ranked candidate, so accepting now secures the best possible match for School_A; there is no higher-priority student to wait for. Even though Student_B ranks School_A third, an acceptance finalizes the match under the rules, and rejecting risks losing the top choice while potentially ending with a lower-priority student later.

conversation.message: Hello School_A admissions team—I'm Student_A. School_A is my first-choice school, and I’m applying because I’m highly committed to enrolling if admitted. I’m excited about the academic environment and would love the opportunity to join your community.

Between them, A is higher on my list than E, so if I must choose now, A is the better match. Consider whether waiting could yield D (top). Student_D’s preferences: C, A, B, E, D; they might apply to C/A first and only come to me if rejected. If I reject A now to hold out for D, I risk ending unmatched or ending with a lower-ranked student later. Also, Student_A has already applied twice (history + this round), signaling strong interest; accepting locks in a high-priority candidate. Therefore accept Student_A.

conversation.message:

Since we prefer leaving the seat unfilled over accepting someone outside the list (and Student_E is on the list), we can still reject strategically to hold out for higher-priority students. Round 3 leaves ample time to wait.

conversation.message:
Dear School_E Admissions,

Thank you again for considering me earlier. Since School_E is the remaining available option and it is on my true preference list, I would like to reaffirm my formal application. I appreciate your reconsideration.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched, and it is on my true preference list (though last). Since remaining unmatched is worse than matching with a listed school, I should apply now and clearly commit if accepted, emphasizing genuine fit and readiness to enroll immediately.

Ideally we want Student_A/Student_C/Student_B, but none are in the inbox this round and we have no current matches. Student_E is on our acceptable list, so accepting secures a filled seat rather than risking ending unmatched if higher-priority students never apply to us (and School_E is last choice for all students, so that risk is high). Given Student_E’s stated willingness to commit immediately, accept now to lock in an acceptable match.
